awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Human Origins and the Molecular Genetic Basis of Craniofacial Evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
The heads of primates, including humans, all have the same basic parts, yet every head is different.  Craniofacial variation has important implications for diet, defense, posture, balance, hearing, vision, and the accommodation of the expanding primate brain.  The skull is a complex adaptive structure, and the question naturally arises pertaining to the genetic mechanisms that assemble and coordinate its shape.  This project will determine whether variation in head shape occurs along similar anatomical axes among living monkeys and apes, their fossil ancestors, a pedigree of 800 extant baboons, and in laboratory mice.  Computerized tomography (CT) scans will be acquired from these heads and used to measure variation in three dimensions.  The genes responsible for this variation will be identified using data from baboon and mouse.  Developmental pathways are shared among mammals, so mice provide an important comparative and experimental basis for primate findings.  The manner by which genes structure variation in head shape will be investigated by combined comparative DNA sequence and bioinformatic analysis, and by engineering similar changes in mice to those seen in baboons.  Many genes doubtlessly contribute to structures like the head, and a general challenge to modern evolutionary and developmental genetics generally is to understand whether some genes are repeatedly involved in similar changes in complex traits over the millions of years and different branches of evolution, or whether different genes in the shared developmental pathways are responsible in each instance.

The project will generate a large amount of data which will be posted on a publicly accessible website along with information on analytical approaches and analyses.  The PIs have a strong record of training women and minority students and they will continue this tradition at all levels from undergraduate to postdoctoral.  Human evolutionary studies have a strong public appeal and this project will be exceptionally popular to the public media.

por.por_cntn:
We examined genetic variation in the size and shape of baboon and mouse skulls to provide valuable information on the genetic underpinning of skull size and shape changes in human and non-human primate evolution. The study is also relevent to understanding the genetic basis for congenital craniofacial abnormalities.

We generated a unique resource of 985 baboon skulls from animals of known family from NIH's Southwest National Primate Research Center. We prepared the skulls, obtained 3D medical CT scan images, and measured the location of anatomical features from the digital images. We also obtained 384 genetic markers spread across the genome from the Primate Center. We found that about 50% of the differences among baboons in the size and shape of their skull were due to genetic differences. We also found that skull features that develop or function together were typically also inherited together. Features that are inherited together often evolve together so it is important to take account of co-inheritance in evolutionary studies.

Using the genetic marker data together with measures of skull size and shape we discovered 69 genomic regions affecting variation in skull size and shape (see Figure). These regions were distributed throughout the genome, each regions containing a few hundred genes. Most locations affected several different features, explaining the basis of trait co-inheritance. Examination of the genes in these regions identified 120 genes most likely responsible for the mapped effects. The unprecedented size of this study in a non-human primate provides robust results for future research.

One of the genes identified, HAND2, is known to affect head and heart development and can cause congenital abnormalities in humans. We identified several DNA differences in this gene that were associated with variations in baboon facial size and shape. We also examined DNA sequence variations across humans and non-human primates and found evidence that this sequenced had evolved in response to selection to modify skull size and shape. This provides a glimpse into the molecular evolutionary basis for human and non-human primate skull evolution.

Our second study population is a specially outbred set of mice. Every generation of breeding breaks the genome into smaller and smaller pieces so that we can fine-map genes affecting skull size and shape. A comparable study would require 250 years in baboons and about 1000 years in humans. This is the power added by using an animal model.Our study included 1139 mice from 140 full-sibling families. Skeletons were prepared and skulls imaged in a high-resolution microCT scanner. Skull feature locations were recorded from the images. We know about every genetic variation across the whole genome in our mouse population but scored 3072 genetic markers to identify genomic regions affecting skull size and shape. We found that 78% of the differences in the mice were due to genetic differences. This high level of genetic effect is due to the special breeding plan utilized.

We mapped 85 specific genome regions affecting skull size and shape, each region representing only 0.1% of the genome and containing 10 to 20 genes. Most locations affected multiple skull features. The effect of each individual region is small but they collectively account for a very strong genetic effect.

We are currently identifying the genes responsible for the mapped genetic effects in these mice. We are also correlating our results across mouse, baboon, and human. The results of the human genome project allow us to identify the same region across human, baboon, and mouse genomes. The genomic regions we have identified are likely to be responsible for the evolution of human and non-human primate skull size and shape. They are also good candidates for genes causing human congenital craniofacial syndromes.
